image.altText: Colombia's Linda Caceido high-fives a teammate after a game against Korea Republic at the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: It's day six of the Women's World Cup, featuring co-hosts New Zealand and Norway, who knocked the Matildas out of the last World Cup. Follow live.

title.children: Teenage star scores for Colombia in opening World Cup win, while Korean 16yo breaks record

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Colombia hangs on to its 2-0 half-time lead and opens its Women's World Cup account with a win for the first time. The match at the Sydney Football Stadium was the final tournament opener, with Korea, ranked 17th, no doubt disappointed to go down to the 25th-ranked South Americans. South Korea was pretty thoroughly outplayed in that one, barely threatening aside from a couple of chances at the end of each half. Meanwhile, Colombia's goals came from a penalty for handball and a goalkeeper blunder, so they will have to improve their execution if they're to match it with a high-flying German side on Sunday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Colombia wraps up first round of group games with a 2-0 win over South Korea

props.alt: Colombia players smile while South Korean players talk in the foreground at the Women's World Cup.

children.content: (ABC News: Brendan Esposito)
Colombia hangs on to its 2-0 half-time lead and opens its Women's World Cup account with a win for the first time.
The match at the Sydney Football Stadium was the final tournament opener, with Korea, ranked 17th, no doubt disappointed to go down to the 25th-ranked South Americans.
South Korea was pretty thoroughly outplayed in that one, barely threatening aside from a couple of chances at the end of each half.
Meanwhile, Colombia's goals came from a penalty for handball and a goalkeeper blunder, so they will have to improve their execution if they're to match it with
a high-flying German side
on Sunday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Casey Phair enters the fray for South Korea as a substitute for Choe Yuri in the 78th minute and becomes the youngest player at a men's or Women's World Cup at just 16 years and 26 days old. She's also the first multi-racial player to turn out for the South Korean national team, men's or women's. She's just, and I have to say just, eclipsed Ifeanyi Chiejine, who played for Nigeria 34 days after her 16th birthday at the 1999 World Cup.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A new youngest-ever World Cup player

children.content: Casey Phair enters the fray for South Korea as a substitute for Choe Yuri in the 78th minute and becomes the youngest player at a men's or Women's World Cup at just 16 years and 26 days old.

props.alt: Casey Phair walks on the field in a white South Korea kit at the Women's World Cup

children.content: The Korean-American has played for South Korea's junior teams but this his her first game at senior level.
(Getty)
She's also the first multi-racial player to turn out for the South Korean national team, men's or women's.
She's just, and I have to say just, eclipsed Ifeanyi Chiejine, who played for Nigeria 34 days after her 16th birthday at the 1999 World Cup.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: Colombia 2-0 South Korea

image.altText: Stocks displayed on a screen at the ASX

items.synopsis: Investors are bracing for Australia's inflation data, US tech earnings and global central bank meetings. ASIC launches court action against Vanguard. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX on the rise, ASIC takes Vanguard to court alleging greenwashing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wesfarmer will merge its discount department stores, Kmart and Target to save costs, although the stores and branding will remain separate. The restructure means that Kmart and Target will be run as the one business with a value of $10 billion. Here's Kmart Group managing director Ian Bailey: "The announcements today are an internal reorganisation of our support offices and there are no impacts to the Kmart or Target stores." " With customers now demanding value more than ever, this new operating model will unlock a new level of scale and productivity across both brands, so we can deliver even greater value to our customers in the future." "For store networks and 50,000 store team members – it’s business as usual – as we continue to focus on providing the best value products to the thousands of customers in Australia and New Zealand who choose to shop at Kmart or Target every day." Mr Bailey says there will be a "handful" of redundancies mostly in technology and merchandising. Kmart chief executive John Gualtieri will run the combined business. Griffith University Business Lab director Graeme Hughes says the move comes after Kmart's success overshadowed Target's performance. "This differentiation      seeks to appeal to a wider range of shoppers and strengthen the      competitiveness of both brands."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Kmart and Target $10 billion merger

children.content: Wesfarmer will merge its discount department stores, Kmart and Target to save costs, although the stores and branding will remain separate.
The restructure means that Kmart and Target will be run as the one business with a value of $10 billion.
Here's Kmart Group managing director Ian Bailey:
"The announcements today are an internal reorganisation of our support offices and there are no impacts to the Kmart or Target stores."

" With customers now demanding value more than ever, this new operating model will unlock a new level of scale and productivity across both brands, so we can deliver even greater value to our customers in the future."

"For store networks and 50,000 store team members – it’s business as usual – as we continue to focus on providing the best value products to the thousands of customers in Australia and New Zealand who choose to shop at Kmart or Target every day."
Mr Bailey says there will be a "handful" of redundancies mostly in technology and merchandising.
Kmart chief executive John Gualtieri will run the combined business.
Griffith University Business Lab director Graeme Hughes says the move comes after Kmart's success overshadowed Target's performance.
"This differentiation      seeks to appeal to a wider range of shoppers and strengthen the      competitiveness of both brands."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As you've been hearing the corporate regulator is accusing investment firm Vanguard of "greenwashing". The Australian Securities and Investments Commission alleges Vanguard marketed a fund to investors seeking an ethical option, but fossil fuels were among the fund's investments. ASIC is suing Vanguard and accusing it of misleading conduct and statements. Vanguard says it moved quickly to inform investors and improve its product disclosure statement, and has fully cooperated with ASIC. ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court told Alicia Barry on ABC News Channel that Vanguard promised its investors that the product would be screened to exclude bond issuers with significant business activities in certain industries, including fossil fuels.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC alleges Vanguard misled investors

children.content: As you've been hearing the corporate regulator is accusing investment firm Vanguard of "greenwashing".
The Australian Securities and Investments Commission alleges Vanguard marketed a fund to investors seeking an ethical option, but fossil fuels were among the fund's investments.
ASIC is suing Vanguard and accusing it of misleading conduct and statements.
Vanguard says it moved quickly to inform investors and improve its product disclosure statement, and has fully cooperated with ASIC.

ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court told Alicia Barry on ABC News Channel that Vanguard promised its investors that the product would be screened to exclude bond issuers with significant business activities in certain industries, including fossil fuels.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China has announced a number of stimulus measures to boost its slowing economy. China's economic planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, unveiled plans to promote private investment. And China's top decision making body, the Politburo, said it would "step up economic policy adjustments" to expand domestic demand and lift confidence. "Currently China's economy is facing new difficulties and challenges, which mainly arise from insufficient domestic demand, difficulties in the operation of some enterprises, risks and hidden dangers in key areas, as well as a grim and complex external environment," Xinhua quoted the Politburo as saying at a meeting chaired by Chinese President Xi Jinping. China's economy slowed down from April to June because of weaker demand at home and abroad, although it did expand by 6.3 per cent over the year to June, a step up from the year to March. Economists at Barclays say while the Politburo meeting signalled more support for the economy, it fell short of offering large scale stimulus. "We view this as a signal that the government would stabilise growth around its target but refrain from an outsized policy response, given the top leaders' intended shift in focus to quality growth." Barclay's Yingke Zhou, Ying Zhang, and Jian Chang are predicting more targeted stimulus instead of the big spending packages of the past. They expect further interest rate cuts, more special bond issuance by local governments, and other measures including lending by policy banks to support infrastructure investment, especially green infrastructure investment. "We think the PBOC (People's Bank of China) has already entered a rate cutting cycle, and expect a 10 basis point (0.1 percentage point) cut every quarter through the first quarter of 2024 to reduce financing costs in the economy, along with 40 to 60 basis points of mortgage rate cuts for both existing and new housing loans." They also expect the central bank to further lower funding costs for financial institutions. The Politburo also called for measures to encourage spending on big ticket items including cars, electronic products and furniture, as well as promoting spending on services like sports and leisure. China's Commerce Ministry has already announced a plan to boost consumption of household goods, which includes a directive to local governments to increase the renovation of old homes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Barclays expects more targeted Chinese stimulus

children.content: China has announced a number of stimulus measures to boost its slowing economy.
China's economic planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, unveiled plans to promote private investment.
And China's top decision making body, the Politburo, said it would "step up economic policy adjustments" to expand domestic demand and lift confidence.

"Currently China's economy is facing new difficulties and challenges, which mainly arise from insufficient domestic demand, difficulties in the operation of some enterprises, risks and hidden dangers in key areas, as well as a grim and complex external environment," Xinhua quoted the
Politburo as saying at a meeting chaired by Chinese President Xi Jinping.
China's economy slowed down from April to June because of weaker demand at home and abroad, although it did expand by 6.3 per cent over the year to June, a step up from the year to March.
Economists at Barclays say while the Politburo meeting signalled more support for the economy, it fell short of offering large scale stimulus.
"We view this as a signal that the government would stabilise growth around its target but refrain from an outsized policy response, given the top leaders' intended shift in focus to quality growth."
Barclay's Yingke Zhou, Ying Zhang, and Jian Chang are predicting more targeted stimulus instead of the big spending packages of the past.

They expect further interest rate cuts, more special bond issuance by local governments, and other measures including lending by policy banks to support infrastructure investment, especially green infrastructure investment.

"We think the PBOC (People's Bank of China) has already entered a rate cutting cycle, and expect a 10 basis point (0.1 percentage point) cut every quarter through the first quarter of 2024 to reduce financing costs in the economy, along with 40 to 60 basis points of mortgage rate cuts for both existing and new housing loans."
They also expect the central bank to further lower funding costs for financial institutions.
The Politburo also called for measures to encourage spending on big ticket items including cars, electronic products and furniture, as well as promoting spending on services like sports and leisure.
China's Commerce Ministry has already announced a plan to boost consumption of household goods, which includes a directive to local governments to increase the renovation of old homes.

(Wind, Barclays Research)
